result.reason: GetScreenById() accesses Screen.AllScreens[i] without bounds-checking after a monitor disconnect shrinks the array, causing IndexOutOfRangeException; fix is a one-line guard plus zeroing _sysMenSubItems in ResetScreenList().
result.approach: In GetScreenById(), add 'if (i >= Screen.AllScreens.Length) continue;' before the return; in ResetScreenList(), call Array.Clear(_sysMenSubItems, 0, _sysMenSubItems.Length) to prevent stale slot matches.

attempts.raw_output:
The root cause is clear. In `GetScreenById`, the loop iterates all 51 slots of `_sysMenSubItems` and returns `Screen.AllScreens[i]` â€” but if a monitor disconnects between menu build and click, `Screen.AllScreens.Length` shrinks and `Screen.AllScreens[i]` throws `IndexOutOfRangeException`. The `_sysMenSubItems` array is also never zeroed between rebuilds, leaving stale entries.
